Jessica Aber’s death feels like one of those stories that’s meant to fade quietly into the background — a tragic headline that people are supposed to forget. But when a career prosecutor who spent her life chasing Russian cybercriminals, CIA leaks, and war criminals turns up dead just weeks after resigning, forgetting isn’t an option. Aber, the former U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia, was found dead at her home in Alexandria on March 22. She was 43 years old. Police haven’t said how she died, but the timing — and her unfinished business — makes it impossible to ignore. THE PROSECUTOR WHO WOULDN’T BACK DOWN Jessica Aber wasn’t just a lawyer — she was the person you sent in when things got messy. In January, just before her resignation, Aber helped put Asif Rahman, a former CIA analyst, behind bars for leaking top-secret information about Israeli military plans against Iran. The information ended up splashed across social media in October 2024. Aber didn’t mince words when Rahman pleaded guilty. She warned that his leak had “placed lives at risk” and “compromised our ability to collect vital intelligence in the future.” That’s prosecutor-speak for this guy seriously screwed things up. Whatever Rahman leaked, it wasn’t just embarrassing — it was dangerous. BIG CASES, BIGGER ENEMIES Aber’s cases didn’t stop there. In November 2024, her office prosecuted a Virginia-based company accused of funneling sensitive U.S. technology to a Russian telecom firm with Kremlin ties. It wasn’t exactly an accident — the company allegedly disguised shipments and played fast and loose with American tech that Russia wasn’t supposed to have. Then there was the war crimes indictment. Aber’s office charged four Russian-linked individuals with torturing and unlawfully detaining a U.S. national in Ukraine. She wasn’t just making legal noise — she was putting serious pressure on powerful figures with deep connections. Aber’s career was a parade of people you wouldn’t want showing up at your funeral — oligarchs, cybercriminals, and corrupt players with resources to make problems disappear. A SUSPICIOUS EXIT Aber resigned in January 2025, just after Donald Trump returned to power. Nobody’s said she was forced out, but resigning from one of the country’s most powerful U.S. Attorney’s offices weeks after jailing a rogue CIA analyst feels a little too clean. It’s not hard to imagine why someone like Aber might suddenly find herself in a tight spot. Trump’s return came with a wave of loyalty tests and DOJ shakeups — and Aber’s aggressive pursuit of Russian networks and CIA leaks doesn’t exactly scream “team player” in this new political climate. If she was pressured to resign, what cases got quietly buried when she left? A SYSTEM THAT’S GONE SOFT ON POWER The Supreme Court’s ruling in July 2024 handed Trump near-total immunity for “core presidential powers,” including military command. Justice Sonia Sotomayor warned that this decision could allow a president to order an assassination — and face no legal consequences. By the time Aber resigned, that ruling had already cast a long shadow over the Department of Justice. Prosecutors like Aber — the kind who took on powerful players with foreign connections — were now working in an environment where accountability had been gutted. If Aber’s investigations had exposed something that threatened powerful interests, the court’s ruling would have made it easier for those interests to apply pressure — or worse — without consequence. Her resignation may have been voluntary. It may not have been. But by the time Aber walked away from her post, the guardrails protecting prosecutors like her were already crumbling. WHAT DID ABER KNOW? Jessica Aber knew things that mattered — things that powerful people wanted buried. She chased down Russian cybercriminals, locked up a CIA leaker who compromised military intelligence, and tangled with foreign operatives who wouldn’t hesitate to make problems disappear. Now she’s gone, and the timing stinks. Maybe her death was just an awful coincidence. Maybe it wasn’t. But when the people investigating corruption start turning up dead, there’s only one responsible thing to do: Start asking louder questions. Via MSNBC{News Junkies}

News: Sen. Jeanne Shaheen (D-N.H.), fresh off her retirement announcement, is set to spearhead a major effort aimed at maximizing Ukraine’s leverage in the ongoing Trump-led peace talks with Russia.  The bipartisan push (Tillis/Graham among the R’s involved) will be modeled after CAATSA, the Russia sanctions bill the Senate passed 98-2 in 2017.  The goal is to strengthen that sanctions regime, codify sanctions that have been imposed via executive order since then, and, by extension, make it harder for Trump to lift sanctions on Russia as part of any peace deal.  The Graham-led portion would would lay out a series of sanctions that would be triggered if Russia re-invades Ukraine. This would help reassure Kyiv over its concerns that Russia wouldn’t abide by a diplomatic agreement anyway.  Needless to say, this is a huge undertaking, and the political environment today (i.e., GOP willingness to back Trump into a corner) is not what it was in 2017.  https://punchbowl.news/article/foreign-policy/shaheens-bipartisan-bid-to-bolster-ukraine/

The Art of Silovik Rivalry: How Russia’s Intelligence Agencies Sabotage Each Other to Survive  In the architecture of the Russian state under Vladimir Putin, few dynamics are as central, opaque, and corrosively essential as the rivalries between the country’s intelligence and security services. What appears externally as a monolithic silovik system—a vertical chain of command run by men in uniform—is in fact a fragmented, competitive, and often mutually hostile ecosystem of power centers, each with its own agenda, loyalty networks, revenue channels, and vision of statehood. Far from being unified, the FSB, GRU, SVR, Rosgvardiya, and affiliated structures operate under a doctrine that incentivizes institutional sabotage, information hoarding, and the covert undermining of one another. This is not a flaw in the system. It is the system. And it is a feature deeply embedded in both the operational logic of the post-Soviet intelligence complex and the personal power strategy of Vladimir Putin himself.  The roots of this rivalry extend back to the late 1990s and early 2000s, when Putin, a former KGB lieutenant colonel, began consolidating power by empowering the so-called siloviki—former and active members of the intelligence, military, and internal security apparatuses. Drawing on a Chekist worldview, Putin sought to stabilize the post-Yeltsin state not by dissolving the old KGB legacy, but by fracturing it across newly competing organs. The FSB (Federal Security Service) inherited internal counterintelligence, surveillance, and domestic control. The SVR (Foreign Intelligence Service) took over foreign human intelligence and diplomatic coverage. The GRU (Main Intelligence Directorate of the General Staff) remained under the Ministry of Defense, responsible for military espionage and covert operations abroad. Alongside them stood the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Federal Guard Service (FSO), and later, the National Guard (Rosgvardiya), all structured in ways that created overlapping jurisdictions and ambiguous mandates.  What began as compartmentalization for control quickly evolved into sustained bureaucratic conflict. Each agency built its own networks of influence, media proxies, informal kompromat channels, and budgetary patrons. This was exacerbated by the fact that loyalty to the president was rewarded more than inter-agency cooperation. Rather than competing on performance or shared strategic goals, services competed for proximity to Putin, influence in the Security Council, control of sensitive investigations, and control over arrest powers—particularly those involving elite corruption. The result has been a culture of perpetual maneuvering, in which intelligence agencies invest as much time neutralizing each other as they do pursuing external enemies.  A defining moment in this internal struggle came with the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in 2006. The former FSB officer, who had defected to the United Kingdom and exposed various crimes committed by his former colleagues, was murdered using radioactive polonium-210—an act widely attributed to operatives linked to the FSB’s Directorate for Special Operations. Western intelligence agencies quickly traced the method and suspects, but within Russia, the assassination also served a secondary purpose. It sent a message not only to dissidents abroad but to rival siloviki: the FSB had operational supremacy in targeted eliminations and a mandate to act extraterritorially. According to testimony from former insiders like Mikhail Trepashkin and analysts like Andrei Soldatov, this led to friction with elements in the SVR and GRU, who saw the FSB’s increasing reach as a violation of inter-service boundaries.  Further evidence of these rivalries surfaced in the aftermath of the failed Novichok assassination of Sergei Skripal in Salisbury in 2018. The operation, conducted by officers of the GRU’s Unit 29155, became a public embarrassment after Bellingcat and Western intelligence agencies identified the suspects within weeks. Their travel records, aliases, and photos were exposed online. Rather than protecting their own, elements within the Russian system began leaking additional details. Open-source investigators were able to confirm the officers’ identities with help from data brokers who reportedly had connections to competing Russian agencies or disgruntled insiders. The implication was clear: someone inside Russia wanted the GRU exposed. FSB-linked media outlets subtly amplified the narrative of GRU incompetence, further suggesting intra-service sabotage.  This dynamic is not limited to high-profile assassination failures. It extends to cyber operations, arrest campaigns, and control over corruption probes. The FSB’s Center for Information Security (TsIB), tasked with counter-cyberintelligence, was embroiled in scandal in 2016 when its deputy head Sergei Mikhailov was arrested by his own colleagues on charges of treason. The case, shrouded in secrecy, involved leaked information to U.S. intelligence and internal accusations that the FSB was sabotaging rival cyber units within the GRU and SVR. According to Russian investigative outlets like The Bell and Novaya Gazeta, the arrests were tied to turf battles over control of Russia’s cyber doctrine—who owns offensive capacity, who manages proxies, and who reports directly to the Kremlin.  Meanwhile, the FSB has long used its investigatory powers to detain or intimidate officers from other services. The GRU has reportedly lost several of its own officers to FSB probes, particularly in cases involving financial fraud or unauthorized operations. These arrests serve multiple functions: they eliminate rivals, consolidate budgetary control, and reinforce FSB dominance. But they also erode trust and lead to operational paralysis, as field agents become reluctant to act without layers of approval for fear of internal betrayal.  Even foreign operations are now shaped by this rivalry. During the Donbas conflict, the FSB and GRU ran parallel operations: the FSB focused on recruitment, surveillance, and political control in occupied territories, while the GRU managed sabotage groups and direct military support. Their coordination was often dysfunctional, leading to overlapping missions, compromised fieldwork, and missed strategic objectives. Ukrainian intelligence intercepts and Russian field reports confirmed that mid-level officers from both agencies clashed over chain-of-command issues, especially during the early stages of the 2014–2015 campaign.  Putin, far from resolving these conflicts, has cultivated them. He encourages rivalry as a mechanism of control, ensuring that no single service becomes strong enough to challenge his authority. Senior intelligence officials often report directly to him, bypassing ministerial channels and weakening interagency communication. Promotions are based less on institutional success than on personal loyalty and the ability to discredit rivals. The result is a centrifugal security system where internal sabotage is not an aberration but a currency of power.  For Russia’s intelligence services, the enemy is not only abroad. It is across the street, in another building, briefing another general, chasing the same budget line, leaking to the same Kremlin fixer. This is not Cold War discipline. It is a post-Soviet struggle for survival in a system that feeds on rivalry, suspicion, and silence. Intelligence in Russia today is not simply about acquiring information or conducting operations. It is about surviving your colleagues long enough to be heard by the president—and sabotaging them before they sabotage you. That is the logic. That is the culture. And that, in Putin’s Russia, is the art of silovik rivalry.
